articles.headline: India to Ease Retail Rules for Foreign Companies
articles.snippet: The decision by the government opens the door for Wal-Mart, Tesco, Ikea and other firms to establish a presence in one of the world’s biggest markets.
articles.abstract: The decision by the government opens the door for Wal-Mart, Tesco, Ikea and other firms to establish a presence in one of the world’s biggest markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — The Indian government decided on Thursday to allow foreign retailers like Wal-Mart and Tesco to open stores in the country, the first time that policy makers have moved to open India’s vast and fast-growing retail market to outsiders.

articles.headline: In Debt Crisis, a Silver Lining for Germany
articles.snippet: Since 2009, Germany and a handful of other countries have benefited significantly from cheaper borrowing as investors diverted cash from riskier assets.
articles.abstract: Since 2009, Germany and a handful of other countries have benefited significantly from cheaper borrowing as investors diverted cash from riskier assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Someone, somewhere, usually makes money from bad news. With Europe’s debt crisis, that — at least until this week — was Germany.

articles.headline: It Shouldn’t Take a Panic to Spur Responsibility
articles.snippet: Economic fear continued to spread as the European Central Bank, Germany and the rest of the Continent fail to get on the same page.
articles.abstract: Economic fear continued to spread as the European Central Bank, Germany and the rest of the Continent fail to get on the same page.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If it is known that the Bank of England is freely advancing on what in ordinary times is reckoned a good security — on what is then commonly pledged and easily convertible — the alarm of the solvent merchants and bankers will be stayed. But if securities, really good and usually convertible, are refused by the Bank, the alarm will not abate, the other loans made will fail in obtaining their end, and the panic will become worse and worse.”

articles.headline: Friday’s Deals May Not Be the Best
articles.snippet: For many products, the lowest prices tend to come at other times of the year, despite all the ads that suggest otherwise.
articles.abstract: For many products, the lowest prices tend to come at other times of the year, despite all the ads that suggest otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oren Etzioni writes articles about artificial intelligence for scholarly journals, is a renowned expert on data mining and gained fame when Microsoft paid $115 million for Farecast, an airline-ticket price predictor he founded.

articles.headline: To Advance Their Cause, Foundations Buy Stocks
articles.snippet: A number of foundations are making investments to connect with profit-making ventures that jibe with their missions.
articles.abstract: A number of foundations are making investments to connect with profit-making ventures that jibe with their missions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation invested $10 million to acquire a stake in Liquidia Technologies, a biotechnology company working on new ways to deliver vaccines.

articles.headline: Image Expert Shapes Romney (His Hair, Anyway)
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s longtime stylist says his customer prefers a “very controlled” look for his his most distinctive physical feature.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s longtime stylist says his customer prefers a “very controlled” look for his his most distinctive physical feature.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELMONT, Mass. — Voters routinely ask about it on the campaign trail. Pundits chronicle the slightest changes in its presentation. There is a Facebook page devoted to it — not to mention an entire blog. “Has it always been this good?” read a recent online entry.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: African Union Force Makes Strides Inside Somalia
articles.snippet: The efforts of its troops have put the African Union in the driver’s seat of an intensifying international effort to wipe out Somalia’s Shabab militants, once and for all.
articles.abstract: The efforts of its troops have put the African Union in the driver’s seat of an intensifying international effort to wipe out Somalia’s Shabab militants, once and for all.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — When the first batch of African Union peacekeepers landed at Mogadishu’s decrepit airport in 2007, they were immediately shelled by insurgents with mortars and given little chance of success. This was Somalia after all, the graveyard of several other doomed interventions, and the African Union soldiers were a last resort for a deeply troubled mission.

articles.headline: For Black Friday First-Timers, Not a Night of Conversion
articles.snippet: Shoppers on their initial Black Friday excursions found good deals, but many did not seem to think it was worth braving the crowds.
articles.abstract: Shoppers on their initial Black Friday excursions found good deals, but many did not seem to think it was worth braving the crowds.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were the Black Friday novices: people who, drawn by the earlier-than-usual store openings or economic necessity, decided to try their hands at shopping on the busiest day of the retail year.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Christopher Maag

articles.headline: Banks’ Ties to Olympus Scrutinized
articles.snippet: Michael C. Woodford, who remains a director of the company but who left Japan after he was fired, returned this week to meet with investigators looking into the scandal surrounding the company.
articles.abstract: Michael C. Woodford, who remains a director of the company but who left Japan after he was fired, returned this week to meet with investigators looking into the scandal surrounding the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A number of European banks are under investigation by Japanese authorities to determine whether they helped the management of Olympus hide irregular payments, according to a person with detailed knowledge of the government’s continuing investigation.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Ben Protess
